item.title: Trump Meets May in London: Live Updates
item.description: On the second day of his three-day state visit to Britain, the president spoke with Prime Minister Theresa May while protesters mobilized in London.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain and President Trump in London on Tuesday.

item.title: Sudan’s Military Abandons Talks and Opens Fire on Democracy Protesters
item.description: As many as 31 people were killed, according to witnesses, as power-sharing talks between pro-democracy protesters and the country’s military rulers collapsed.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Pro-democracy protesters closed a street in Khartoum, Sudan, on Monday as security forces tried to disperse a sit-in outside the country’s military headquarters.

item.title: ‘In the Streets, Anguish, Fury and Tears’
item.description: Read excerpts from The Times’s on-the-ground coverage of the Chinese government’s 1989 crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Above, a student placed debris in front of an armored personnel carrier in Tiananmen Square in Beijing on June 4, 1989. This photo ran on the front page of The New York Times that day.

item.title: Caught Between U.S. and Taliban, a Family Dies and the Survivor Seeks Justice
item.description: An investigation shows an American airstrike killed 12 family members in eastern Afghanistan during a battle against insurgents.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: French ISIS Supporters on Death Row in Iraq Ask for Mercy
item.description: France is facing criticism from rights advocates that 11 of its citizens and one resident will hang in Iraq for supporting ISIS. Will it try to save them?
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: The Iraqi Criminal Court in Baghdad’s Karkh district, where the trials for 11 French citizens and one French resident were held.

item.title: Trump’s Love Affair With the Royal Family Dates Back to His Mother
item.description: As a 6-year-old, Trump sat beside his mother as she watched Queen Elizabeth’s coronation, enthralled at the gilded splendor. His father scoffed at the ceremony.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Trump: The Art of the Deal (Book)
item.media:description: President Trump met with Queen Elizabeth for tea at Windsor Castle in 2018.

item.title: Trump Insults London Mayor as ‘Loser’ as He Pays Tribute to the Queen
item.description: Queen Elizabeth welcomed Mr. Trump to Buckingham Palace, while he engaged in an ugly dispute with London’s mayor, calling him a “stone cold loser.”
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Maggie Haberman
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: President Trump and the first lady, Melania Trump, at Buckingham Palace with Queen Elizabeth II in London on Monday.

item.title: 8 Missing Climbers in Indian Himalayas Are Assumed Dead, Officials Say, Citing Photographs
item.description: The officials said aerial photographs taken Monday showed at least five bodies on Nanda Devi, India’s second-tallest mountain. The climbers were last heard from on May 26.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Suhasini Raj
item.media:description: Nanda Devi, India’s second-highest mountain, in 2014.

item.title: Canadian Inquiry Calls Killings of Indigenous Women Genocide
item.description: A long-anticipated report into the killings and disappearances of Indigenous women and girls also called for changes to the criminal code.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada speaking on Monday during the closing ceremony of the National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls in Gatineau, Quebec.

item.title: Italy’s Prime Minister Delivers Ultimatum to Warring Coalition Partners
item.description: Giuseppe Conte told the populist government’s battling coalition partners that if they didn’t stop paralyzing the government, he would quit and bring the government down with him.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte of Italy at a news conference in Rome on Monday.

item.title: All 9 of Sri Lanka’s Muslim Ministers Resign, as Bombing Backlash Intensifies
item.description: The resignations were in response to a hunger strike by a Buddhist monk who said he would fast until he died unless one of the ministers, as well as two Muslim governors, were removed from office.
item.dc:creator: Dharisha Bastians and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: The Muslim ministers at a news conference on Monday announcing their resignations.

item.title: South African Wine Farmer in Land Dispute Is Shot Dead
item.description: It was too soon to say whether the killing of Stefan Smit, a prominent white farmer, was a random criminal act or was related to bitter arguments about land ownership.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Kimon de Greef
item.media:description: Stefan Smit with friends at his Louisenhoff vineyard outside of Stellenbosch, in the Western Cape province of South Africa.

item.title: On YouTube’s Digital Playground, an Open Gate for Pedophiles
item.description: The site’s automated recommendation system, at times drawing on home movies of unwitting families, created a vast video catalog of prepubescent children.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher and Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Maria Magdalena Arrellaga for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I got scared by the number of views,” said a Brazilian woman, Christiane C., whose young daughter posted a video of herself.

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte Says He ‘Cured’ Himself From Being Gay
item.description: The Philippines president, in calling a political rival gay, said he used to be gay himself but was cured with the help of “beautiful women.”
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez and Jennifer Jett
item.media:description: President Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines in Manila last month.

item.title: For Trump, U.K. State Visit Is a (Royal) Family Affair
item.description: The president’s children seemed to materialize overnight in London. But their appearance with the British royals was the culmination of a month’s planning.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman and Katie Rogers
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Ivanka Trump, second right, and her husband, Jared Kushner, right, watching the welcome ceremony at Buckingham Palace with other members of the American entourage on Monday.

item.title: How the Tiananmen Massacre Shocked, Then Inspired a Chinese Political Cartoonist
item.description: The authorities in China have moved quickly to censor the cartoonist, Badiucao, whose work uses bold — and critics say sometimes vulgar — imagery.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Christina Simons for The New York Times
item.media:description: The dissident Chinese cartoonist Badiucao posted street art in Melbourne, Australia, on Monday, the day before the 30th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square crackdown.

item.title: Trump’s U.K. Trip in Pictures
item.description: On Day 2 of President Trump’s state visit to Britain, he set aside the royal pomp and turned his focus to diplomacy and trade.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Trump and the first lady, Melania Trump, looked over the U.S. Declaration of Independence with Mrs. May of Britain and her husband, Philip.

item.title: Japanese Women Want a Law Against Mandatory Heels at Work
item.description: Thousands of supporters have rallied behind the hashtag #KuToo, a pun based on the words for shoe and pain.
item.dc:creator: Hisako Ueno and Daniel Victor

item.title: Gunman Kills 4 in Darwin, Australia
item.description: The police said a 45-year-old man was arrested. The motive for the shooting spree was unclear, but the authorities ruled out terrorism.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave

item.title: London, Tiananmen Square, Apple: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford

item.title: Australian Police Raid Journalist’s Home Over Surveillance Article
item.description: It was believed to be the first such action against an Australian journalist in more than a decade. A union called the raid “an outrageous attack on press freedom.”
item.dc:creator: Jamie Tarabay

item.title: What Happened After P.G. Wodehouse Was Captured During World War II
item.description: The beloved British humorist — the creator of Wooster and Jeeves — was arrested by the Germans in 1940 and spent the remainder of the war in custody. Here’s how his story unspooled in The Times.
item.dc:creator: Tina Jordan
item.media:description: P.G. Wodehouse in England in 1928. The British writer was captured by German forces in 1940 while he was at his villa in France.

item.title: He Was Looking for Opals. Instead He Found a New Dinosaur Species.
item.description: Scientists reported the discovery in Australia of a plant-eating species, 35 years after a miner brought fossils to a museum in Sydney.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Tarabay and Genevieve Jia Ling Finn

item.title: A Taliban Commander’s Double Life, in a War He Couldn’t Leave Behind
item.description: In one life, he was Zabet Khan, a 25-year-old with a fondness for selfies. In the other, he was Commander Zarqawi, veteran of a war he couldn’t escape.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Poland Marks an Anniversary, Not in Solidarity, but Division
item.description: Three decades after the first elections after Communism, a struggle over control of the narrative of the past could determine the country’s future.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader, speaking to workers at the shipyard in Gdansk, Poland, during a strike in 1980.

item.title: Tiananmen Anniversary Draws Silence in Beijing but Emotion in Hong Kong
item.description: Thirty years after hundreds, possibly thousands, of demonstrators were killed, memories of the bloodshed remain fraught.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin and Austin Ramzy
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thousands of people gathered at Victoria Park in Hong Kong on Tuesday, the 30th anniversary of the crackdown on a student-led democracy movement at Beijing’s Tiananmen Square.

item.title: Protesters Hit London Streets, With a Giant Trump Balloon in Tow
item.description: Hopes for a big turnout appeared to be falling short, despite the return of a giant orange balloon depicting President Trump as a scowling baby in a diaper and holding a smartphone.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeginsu
item.media:description: A protest against President Trump in Trafalgar Square in London on Tuesday.

item.title: Britain, Tech, Climate Change: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic

item.title: The Tiananmen Square Anniversary: A Guide to Our Coverage
item.description: The bloody 1989 crackdown crushed a student-led movement for democracy and helped shape China’s government for years to come.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: People gathered at Tiananmen Square during a pro-democracy protest in Beijing, in 1989.

item.title: iTunes, Britain, Jeopardy: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Shannon and Hiroko Masuike

item.title: Mexico Cracks Down on Migrants, After Pressure From Trump to Act
item.description: Although President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico had opened his arms to migrants, his officials have recently ramped up detentions and deportations, following pressure from President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Kirk Semple
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Estanislao Hernandez, 40, and his son, Elder, 10, migrants from Honduras, were detained by the Mexican authorities at a checkpoint on the outskirts of Tapachula, Mexico.

item.title: Tiananmen Square, Apple, Elaine Chao: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Our Asia editor reflects on Tiananmen Square.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta

item.title: Trump’s U.K. Trip in Pictures
item.description: Lunch with the queen, and a wreath at Westminster Abbey: The president’s three-day state visit to Britain began with an agenda that was heavy on the pomp.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: President Trump and Mrs. May met at St. James’s Palace.

item.title: 30 Years After Tiananmen, ‘Tank Man’ Remains an Icon and a Mystery
item.description: He is a global symbol of resistance. But who was “Tank Man” and how has he remained a mystery?
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:description: A man stands alone to block a line of tanks heading east on Beijing’s Changan Boulevard in Tiananmen Square on June 5, 1989.

item.title: He Stayed at Tiananmen to the End. Now He Wonders What It Meant.
item.description: Zhou Duo helped evacuate Tiananmen Square in 1989. These days he defends the movement, but sees democracy in retreat in the West and far off in China.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Zhou Duo in Beijing in April.

item.title: United Kingdom, Golden State Warriors, Eid: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford

item.title: Royal Family Hosts Trump in U.K. State Visit
item.description: President Trump began his long-delayed state visit to Britain replete with full honors, including ceremonies, government meetings and a Buckingham Palace banquet.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: President Trump and Queen Elizabeth at Buckingham Palace in London on Monday, along with the first lady, Melania Trump, left, and Prince Charles and his wife, Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall, right.

item.title: One Bomb. 11 Children Killed. And the Evidence That Implicates the U.S.
item.description: A woman and 11 children were killed in an airstrike on a home in Afghanistan last fall. We spoke to the father who was left to search for answers. The United States initially said it was not involved, but after our visual investigation, it changed its story.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert, David Botti, Fahim Abed, Jessica Purkiss and Malachy Browne
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Trump in Britain, China, Pope Francis: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic

item.title: North Korean Official Blamed for Failed Trump Summit Reappears in Public
item.description: Kim Yong-chol, a North Korean party vice chairman, resurfaced this week, despite reports that he had been banished to a labor camp.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Kim Yong-chol, the former North Korean intelligence chief and top nuclear arms negotiator, with President Trump at the White House last year.

item.title: Witnessing China’s 1989 Protests, 1,000 Miles From Tiananmen Square
item.description: As a student, Representative Andy Levin of Michigan experienced firsthand the bloody crackdown against pro-democracy demonstrators.

item.title: For the Chao Family, Deep Ties to the World’s 2 Largest Economies
item.description: The family of Elaine Chao, the transportation secretary, has forged high-level political connections not only in the United States but also in China, where their shipping business has prospered.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton and Michael Forsythe
item.media:description: As transportation secretary, Elaine Chao is the top Trump official overseeing the maritime industry. Her family owns Foremost Group, a shipping company.

item.title: Google Disruptions Affect Gmail, YouTube and Other Sites
item.description: The errors also affected businesses that rely on Google’s technology. Google said the problems were not caused by a cyberattack.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Zaveri
item.media:credit: Christie Hemm Klok for The New York Times
item.media:description: Errors and slowdowns affected a number of Google services on Sunday. The company said they were the result of “high levels of network congestion.”

item.title: A ‘Bridge’ to China, and Her Family’s Business, in the Trump Cabinet
item.description: Elaine Chao has boosted the profile of her family’s shipping company, which benefits from industrial policies in China that are roiling the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Michael Forsythe, Eric Lipton, Keith Bradsher and Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Elaine Chao, the transportation secretary, oversees the American maritime industry. Her family’s shipping company, Foremost Group, has deep ties to the Chinese elite.

item.title: U.S. Requiring Social Media Information From Visa Applicants
item.description: The State Department is asking visa applicants to submit social media accounts that they have used in the past five years under a new policy that took effect on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:description: The United States Embassy building in central London. The State Department is now requiring visa applicants to submit social media account information for the past five years.

item.title: Trump Administration Says It Will Negotiate With Iran With ‘No Preconditions’
item.description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo’s remarks were the second softening of U.S. policy on Iran recently, even as the U.S. ratchets up military and financial pressure.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, left, and Ignazio Cassis, the Swiss foreign minister, on Sunday in Bellinzona, Switzerland.

item.title: Pope Francis Apologizes to Roma for Mistreatment and Urges European Unity
item.description: “If Europe does not look carefully to future challenges, Europe will dry up,” the pontiff warned on a trip to Romania.
item.dc:creator: Kit Gillet and Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Francis presiding over an Eastern-Rite liturgy on Sunday outside Blaj, Romania.

item.title: Filling Oreo With Toothpaste Earns YouTube Prankster a Jail Sentence
item.description: A Spanish court gave Kanghua Ren, known as ReSet, a 15-month prison term and ordered him to pay his victim, a homeless man in Barcelona, about $22,300 in compensation.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder

item.title: Cruise Ship Rams Into Tourist Boat and Dock in Venice, Injuring at Least 4
item.description: The huge vessel plowed into a smaller boat on the Giudecca Canal and had people fleeing in panic, reigniting a debate about the dangers of allowing giant ships to pass through the lagoon city.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo

item.title: Algeria Cancels Presidential Election, Setting Up New Impasse
item.description: The Constitutional Council scrapped the July 4 vote, giving in to the demands of protesters who had no faith in the process.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter

item.title: Trump State Visit to U.K. Faces Turbulence Amid Brexit Chaos
item.description: When the American president arrives in London on Monday, it’s not clear how much more he can shake up a country that is already roiled by the Brexit debacle.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump will arrive in London on Monday for a state visit.

item.title: Acting Defense Chief Sees No Need to Restart Big Military Exercises With South Korea
item.description: Patrick Shanahan said he was confident troops were well prepared despite the halt to large-scale war games in a concession to North Korea.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Acting Defense Secretary Patrick Shanahan in Singapore on Saturday.

item.title: Afghan Peace Marchers Take Cease-Fire Plea Directly to Taliban
item.description: About three dozen activists are heading toward Taliban-controlled territory in southern Afghanistan to ask for a halt to the country’s violence.
item.dc:creator: Fahim Abed

item.title: Leader of Social Democrats, Merkel’s Coalition Partner, Is Resigning
item.description: Andrea Nahles announced she was stepping down after a dismal showing in the European election, raising questions about the future of Chancellor Angela Merkel’s government.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: Andrea Nahles, leader of Germany’s Social Democrats, in Berlin in May.

item.title: The Most Powerful Arab Ruler Isn’t M.B.S. It’s M.B.Z.
item.description: Prince Mohammed bin Zayed expanded the U.A.E.’s power by following America’s lead. He now has an increasingly bellicose agenda of his own. And President Trump seems to be following him.
item.dc:creator: David D. Kirkpatrick
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: President Trump welcoming Prince Mohammed at the White House in 2017.

item.title: What to Know About Prince Mohammed bin Zayed, the Arab Ruler Swaying Trump
item.description: Prince Mohammed, the de facto ruler of the United Arab Emirates, is one of the most influential Arab leaders in Washington. Here are five takeaways from a Times report.
item.dc:creator: David D. Kirkpatrick
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Zayed of Abu Dhabi at the White House in 2017.

item.title: China Strikes Defiant Stance on Trade Against Trump
item.description: In a new white paper, Beijing blamed the United States for the breakdown in trade talks. Some companies, like FedEx, are already feeling pressure from the Chinese government.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson

item.title: Modi’s Problems at Home Overshadow Trump’s Latest Trade Threat to India
item.description: President Trump ended India’s special trade status, hoping to jolt stalled trade talks. But the prime minister is focused on India’s sluggish economy.
item.dc:creator: Vindu Goel
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi with President Trump in 2017. Mr. Modi has made it clear that lifting India’s economy is his priority.

item.title: Boeing Built Deadly Assumptions Into 737 Max, Blind to a Late Design Change
item.description: A system that doomed two flights was expected to engage only rarely and originally used two sensors. Critical decisions were based on those factors even when they no longer applied, employees said.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Natalie Kitroeff, David Gelles and James Glanz
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)
item.media:description: After Boeing removed one of the sensors from an automated flight system on its 737 Max, the jet’s designers and regulators still proceeded as if there would be two.

item.title: U.S. Promises Security Aid, but No Funds, to Guatemala to Curb Migration
item.description: In Guatemala, the homeland security secretary offset requests for restoring funding cuts by offering hands-on assistance from United States agents and investigators.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Toya Sarno Jordan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waiting to greet family members deported from the United States at a repatriation center on Thursday in Guatemala City. More Guatemalans than migrants from any other country are seeking to enter the United States along its southwestern border.

item.title: A Tale of Murder, Revenge and a Canadian Immigrant Dream Gone Wrong
item.description: Vancouver is riveted by the murder trial of a Chinese immigrant, accused of killing his wealthy relative. The story pulls together many strands of recent changes in the city.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Alana Paterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Vancouver mansion where Yuan Gang, a wealthy Chinese immigrant to Canada, was found murdered in 2015.
